title: When will AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. (AMC), the parent company of AMC Theatres, file for bankruptcy?
preds: They are still viable for now.

Adjusting forecast a bit at least for the moment on rumors that some creditors are "pushing" AMC to file for bankruptcy now: https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/12/14/amc-urged-toward-bankruptcy-as-stock-markets-rever/ Also, reportedly no merger in the works with Cinemark: https://www.barrons.com/articles/amc-stock-tumbles-after-hopes-for-a-cinemark-deal-wane-51607973155

The Motley fool has article today by Rich Duprey that AMC entertainment lenders urge it to declare bankruptcy.
IF attendance does not improve drastically by summer 2021 in time for the big blockbusters its game over for AMC.

"AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. needs to raise at least $750 million to stay open and might go bankrupt if the effort doesn’t succeed ... The world’s largest movie-theater chain said in a filing Friday that without new financing, existing cash will be depleted as soon as next month. To remain viable through 2021, AMC is looking at selling more shares, financing from European sources and deals with debt holders including Mudrick Capital Management." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-12-11/amc-movie-theaters-seek-liquidity-lifelines-to-avert-bankruptcy Bankruptcy may come "as soon as" January 2021, which is beyond the scope of this question.

Latest effort to sell more stock may help the company make it through year end https://www.wsj.com/articles/amc-says-it-might-go-bankrupt-if-you-dont-buy-its-stock-11607020845 https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/12/04/why-amc-entertainment-stock-fell-today/

WSJ said they are burning through 100 Million an month (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3cRHGNPRKvg) but with the recent selling of stock (https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/amc-entertainment-raise-844-million-155517996.html) they should be fine.
Passage of time update. AMC may continue to find ways to limp through 2020. https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/11/27/i-want-amc-entertainment-to-live-but-it-will-proba/
There is the potential that the virus trend causes them to file early, but more likely that they continue to limp along as long as vaccine news is good.

While there is a short term rebound in stock price due to vaccine announcements (https://www.marketwatch.com/story/cinema-stock-amc-soars-59-premarket-live-nation-up-14-as-pfizer-vaccine-news-sparks-rally-in-event-stocks-2020-11-09), introduction of a vaccine may not come soon enough for AMC to be able to stretch cash flows (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/20/amc-warns-that-bankruptcy-is-on-the-table-as-cash-runs-low.html).
Hanging on hoping for a miracle.

Updates:
— "AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc AMC.N, the world's largest theater chain, said on Tuesday it would raise cash through a share offering and was working hard to restructure its debt and avoid seeking bankruptcy protection." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-amc-ent-holdg-bankruptcy/amc-to-raise-fresh-capital-as-liquidity-troubles-deepen-idUSKBN2751GJ
— "Analysts say the company is burning more than $100 million a month, and that this week’s capital raise does little to change that. Without new attractions to wrangle moviegoers from their couches, Matt Zloto, an analyst at CreditSights, says AMC is in danger of running out of cash by early next year." https://www.wsj.com/articles/amc-bonds-fall-despite-theater-reopenings-11603385653

"AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc.’s chief executive officer says the cinema chain is doing everything it can to raise fresh cash to weather the Covid-19 pandemic and isn’t considering bankruptcy at the moment. The shares fell more than 20% in New York trading ... Bloomberg News reported earlier, citing people with knowledge of the matter, that the company was considering a range of options that include a potential bankruptcy to ease its debt load as the pandemic keeps moviegoers from attending and studios from supplying films ... Lenders to the world’s biggest cinema chain have also held preliminary talks among themselves about providing financing if AMC decides to file for Chapter 11 court protection, the people said ... AMC said in a filing Tuesday that cash could run out by the end of this year or early in 2021 if attendance doesn’t pick up, and it’s exploring actions to boost liquidity that include asset sales, renegotiating leases, joint ventures or other arrangements with existing business partners, and debt or equity financing. There’s significant risk that its efforts will fall short or fail, AMC warned." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-14/amc-s-ceo-says-company-focused-on-fundraising-not-bankruptcy

https://www.wsj.com/articles/theater-chain-amc-says-it-could-run-out-of-cash-by-year-end-11602593301 This article is cited by others as well - but I have a slightly different take. Talking about selling stock or other actions to keep cash is good. This question is certainly very much a race. Feels like AMC has a good chance to make it to January even if it might be hard to make it longer.

AMC may be able to come up with some more money again (e.g. via asset sales) at least in the short term. 
But "..could run out of cash by year-end (or early next year)" -- stated in October by the company -- is concerning. https://www.wsj.com/articles/theater-chain-amc-says-it-could-run-out-of-cash-by-year-end-11602593301 https://deadline.com/2020/10/cinema-stocks-teeter-wall-street-ponders-possible-amc-entertainment-bankruptcy-1234596738/

“Could run out of money by end of year or early next year.” 
https://deadline.com/2020/10/cinema-stocks-teeter-wall-street-ponders-possible-amc-entertainment-bankruptcy-1234596738/ With Regal closing and new deal with Universal, I don’t see it happening before January 1, taking advantage of holiday movie would I invest in it? Not a chance, but I think they will stay open as long as they have cash.

Paradigm change. Bloomberg 10/13 = "A representative for Leawood, Kansas-based AMC declined to comment. AMC said in a filing Tuesday that cash could run out by the end of this year or early next year if attendance doesn’t pick up, " The cavalry are quarantined with Covid-19 and won't be showing up at the theatre. Even the films are quarantined. I thought they could make it, but now it looks doubtful.
"*could* run out of money by the end of the year..." https://www.wsj.com/podcasts/whats-news/movie-theaters-face-more-uncertainty-as-pandemic-drags-on/B396709C-C2A2-46BC-85B8-F876494999C5

"AMC Entertainment CEO Adam Aron on Thursday defended the company’s decision to continue operating its movie theaters during the coronavirus pandemic, even as one of its top rivals chose to temporarily take its screens dark ... AMC is proceeding with additional reopening plans, including in Washington after receiving clearance from the state to resume operations. By mid-October, the company will have more than 80% of its roughly 600 theaters open — although the key market of New York remains closed." https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/08/amc-ceo-says-keeping-movie-theaters-open-is-the-right-decision.html
Regal has shut down, apparently, leaving AMC as just about the only choice in certain burgs for those who demand expensive greasy popcorn and uncomfortable seats.

"S&P downgraded debt of the world’s biggest chain, AMC Entertainment, calculating it has six months of cash left unless things materially improve ... it lowered its issuer credit rating on AMC to ‘CCC-‘ from ‘CCC+’ — reflecting its view that 'a default, distressed exchange, or redemption appears to be inevitable within six months, absent unanticipated significantly favorable changes in the issuer’s circumstances.'" https://deadline.com/2020/10/sp-cuts-amc-ent-debt-rating-says-chain-has-six-months-of-cash-left-unless-it-raises-more-capital-or-attendance-improves-1234590276/

per @juancambeiro , i see the rich banks taking equity to stave off what will otherwise be a good business to sell later... "Imminent Bankruptcy Likelihood" averted...  https://www.reuters.com/article/amc-ent-holdg-capital/amc-entertainment-to-sell-up-to-15-mln-shares-to-raise-funds-idUSL3N2GL31P

@juancambeiro provides the final nail for me. It's a game of hanging on until people can act "normal". The need is there, the product and the technology for delivery is there, just need a vaccine to restart demand.
https://www.macroaxis.com/invest/ratio/AMCX--Probability-Of-Bankruptcy - probability of bankruptcy from this report is 47%

"AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc said on Thursday it has reached a deal with some banks to sell up to 15 mln shares to raise capital as the movie theater operator reels under the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic." https://www.reuters.com/article/amc-ent-holdg-capital/amc-entertainment-to-sell-up-to-15-mln-shares-to-raise-funds-idUSL3N2GL31P This probably makes a bankruptcy in the near future less likely.
It looks they are going to get money and be able to continue to apply for Fed dollar's at negative rates.

The market is saying Hold not sell.
Assumption is that AMC will hold out for 2020.
Resurgence of theatre openings. http://investor.amctheatres.com/newsroom  https://www.marketwatch.com/story/amcs-stock-gains-as-nearly-80-of-its-movie-theaters-will-be-open-this-weekend-2020-09-11?mod=mw_quote_news  https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/09/02/why-amc-entertainment-stock-jumped-27-in-early-tra/

AMC has enough financing to keep itself afloat well into 2021. While Tenet was a miss, I would expect AMC to try its best to remain afloat to also capture the big blockbusters coming in November (Black Widow and No Time to Die).
Movies have restarted so probably not this year.

Tenet is getting butts into seats this weekend, signaling the start of a long, slow recovery for the industry. Fall and winter may bring some additional setbacks, but this weekend has brought some much-needed positive news.

Good sign: "While the broader stock market had a downbeat ending on Friday, AMC Entertainment Holdings (NYSE:AMC) stock surged ahead by 6.4%. Investors are clearly expecting a good weekend for the company due to the fresh release of a blockbuster film, which should then continue to drive attendance at movie theaters." https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/09/04/why-amc-entertainment-holdings-was-a-stock-market/

Good sign: "Thursday is reopening day for AMC Entertainment Holdings (NYSE:AMC), as it is begins turning back on the lights in 170 of its U.S. cinemas. All told, the company said, it will have almost 300 of its locations open ... This is the second wave of reopenings for the company, which is the largest movie theater chain in the U.S.; the first was smaller, involving over 100 cinemas. AMC said in a press release the reopenings will continue in phases, and the company plans to have around 400 operational by Sept. 3, the date on which the highly anticipated thriller Tenet is scheduled to be released. AMC owns roughly 600 movie theaters throughout the U.S." https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/08/27/amc-entertainment-reopening-another-170-cinemas-on/
sometimes it's better to change your mind and occupy yourself with something else

So far 113 locations opened, at 30% capacity. Each film has two showings a day. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/after-5-months-amc-theaters-cautiously-reopen-doors-2020-08-20 Amc hopes to open 2/3 of its locations by the first weeks of September.  Amc operates about 1006 theatres and 11,091 screens.
Bankruptcy this year seems unlikely, short of Covid coming back bad this winter.
"AMC, the world's largest movie theater chain, is reopening more than 100 US locations on Thursday." https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/20/media/amc-theatres-reopen-coronavirus/index.html

The drive for individuals to get out of the house and do things is immense. If you look at Disney World, it is a theme park located in a state with some of the highest rates of infections of Covid-19. There have still been many people that have traveled to Disney for a vacation. Since most people don't have the money to go to Disney World for a vacation, they will pursue cheaper options like movie theaters. It will be like beaches, people will go when they really shouldn't. Additionally, businesses like Disney, need theaters to stay open to obtain the greatest amount of profits they can from movies. Disney cannot afford a company like AMC to go bankrupt, unless they try to purchase the company for cheap. Potential business owners will not soon invest in starting up local theaters and so for movies to be shown in theaters then the ones out there now are the ones that movie companies will be invested in keeping open.
They have liquidity to May 2021 at the minimum

On account of the paralytic US gummint, it looks like fewer US merrymakers than expected will have any spare money for the rest of the year at least, and most of the rest will not wish sit on somebody else's popcorn butter waiting to be infected.  This does not bode well for AMC.

"AMC Theatres, the nation’s largest movie theater chain, will reopen in the U.S. on Aug. 20 with retro ticket prices of 15 cents per movie ... AMC Entertainment, which owns the chain, said Thursday that it expects to open the doors to more than 100 cinemas — or about a sixth of its nationwide locations — on Aug. 20 with throwback pricing for a day ... AMC and other chains have said they will operate at reduced capacity to facilitate social distancing, along with increased theater cleaning and required mask wearing" [1]. As of 13 August at 11:45AM EST, AMC Entertainment's stock has jumped ~12% [2] since this news broke. I take this as a signal that investors are now more confident AMC Entertainment will survive this crisis, so I am updating accordingly — I'm boosting the probability of no bankruptcy by end the of the year from 65% to 75%.  [1] https://apnews.com/a3794011d38591428c3a6e771d84977a
[2] https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/?symbol=AMC

The questions being, will the studios want to distribute their new offerings in the middle of a pandemic?
It is content that draws the crowds.
Will the cinemas be allowed to open?
Will audiences return if they are open, considering mandatory mask wearing?
Can AMC’s finances whether the storm?
Can AMC’s foreign cinemas sustain the company in the short term?
AMC have signed deal with studios concerning distribution concerning screen time prior to streaming. The studios keep putting back the release dates.
Disney has altered Mulan to be streamed rather than open in the cinemas.
New York and LA are still closed (biggest audiences).
AMC is partially owned by Wanda Group. They have been badly affected by Covid-19 and have been cutting back on their US investments for perhaps political reasons and will not be supporting AMC.  Covid-19 in the US is not receding, with the virus still in the first wave. History dictates there will be further waves, suggesting that the Government(s) will not be allowing a re-opening of cinemas in the near future.
Therefore, the proposal is that AMC will probably file for bankruptcy Q4 of 2020 and perhaps Q1 2021. https://www.healthline.com/health-news/here-are-the-states-where-covid-19-is-increasing  https://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/2020/06/03/amc-theatres-parent-signals-could-face-bankruptcy/3135253001/  https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/08/03/amc-entertainment-restructures-debt-easing-bankrup.aspx  https://www.deseret.com/entertainment/2020/7/8/21317389/coronavirus-amc-bankruptcy-covid-19  https://www.gamespot.com/articles/amc-shifts-reopening-dates-for-theaters-after-more/1100-6480127/  https://www.vox.com/culture/2020/3/10/21173376/coronavirus-cancel-tenet-disney-mulan-streaming  https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/12/21365960/amc-a-list-subscription-covid-19-coronavirus-december-deadline-cancel-reactivate  https://www.indiewire.com/2020/08/tenet-us-press-screenings-1234578216/  https://variety.com/2020/film/news/new-mutants-disney-movie-theaters-august-release-1234731537/  https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/business/story/2020-08-06/amc-theatres-lost-561-million-in-one-quarter-because-of-covid-19
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/08/dire-outlook-for-cinemas-as-coronavirus-resurges-in-us.html  https://www.fitchratings.com/research/corporate-finance/fitch-affirms-wanda-commercial-at-bb-outlook-stable-11-08-2020  https://www.mingtiandi.com/real-estate/outbound-investment/amc-facing-imminent-default-as-covid-19-empties-theatres/  https://www.forbes.com/sites/danidiplacido/2020/06/19/mandatory-masks-or-not-why-would-anyone-want-to-visit-a-movie-theatre-right-now/#14cf5f6059f7  https://www.slashfilm.com/when-will-movie-theaters-reopen/

AMC continues to find ways to reduce its debt load, but certainly not out of the woods yet. However, we should probably consider that the companies helping finance AMCs debt certainly believe that what they're doing will help them last until movies return and AMC reopens.
https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/08/03/amc-entertainment-restructures-debt-easing-bankrup.aspx The future is still uncertain, but I am reverting to my baseline estimate.

"Shares of AMC Entertainment (NYSE:AMC) have jumped today, up by 6% as of 12:55 p.m. EDT, after the movie theater chain reported second-quarter earnings. As expected, COVID-19 absolutely decimated revenue and earnings, but the company is optimistic about reopening its theaters soon ... The media exhibitor said that managing liquidity is its highest priority right now, particularly given it flirted with bankruptcy during the quarter. AMC had $498 million in cash at the end of Q2 and is working to reduce costs. Following the close of the quarter, the company completed a debt exchange offer in July to restructure some of its hefty debt load." https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/08/07/why-amc-stock-jumped-today.aspx

The grim reaper has been pushed out of the way for a while. The movie industry, however, has likely been forever changed by the covid experience. There are just too many other ways to get the same entertainment.

"To complete the debt exchange, S&P Global argued AMC issued $1.46 billion of new second-lien secured notes due 2026, and 'we estimate the lenders are receiving roughly 70 percent to 75 percent par value.' 'Because of this, we view the transaction as a distressed exchange and tantamount to a default on the subordinated notes....'"
https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/amc-theatres-credit-ratings-downgrade-distressed-debt-swap-1305710

"AMC Entertainment holdings has eased a burden that some investors feared could force it into bankruptcy ... On Monday, movie theater chain AMC announced a deal with most of its senior subordinated noteholders that will reduce its $5 billion debt load by $553 million ... The same negotiations will also improve the company's cash and liquidity position between $355 million and $415 million within 18 months. AMC Entertainment has issued 5 million shares of stock to facilitate the deal." https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/08/03/amc-entertainment-restructures-debt-easing-bankrup.aspx

They may not go to bancruptcy at all..
https://www.deseret.com/entertainment/2020/7/8/21317389/coronavirus-amc-bankruptcy-covid-19

They may not go to bancruptcy at all.. 
https://www.deseret.com/entertainment/2020/7/8/21317389/coronavirus-amc-bankruptcy-covid-19
I'm not entirely sure this will happen at all. I've bought enough popcorn from them to keep them afloat for the next three years.

They will stick it out until after the Holiday season and decide then. Even if they do declare Bankruptcy they won't go out of business. I'm not just saying this because I still have my card for a free slushy either.

The Cancellation of some large movie releases. The new Avatar and Star Wars films have been delayed by a year, Mulan has been removed from schedules completely. These delays combined with the company debt levels make survival difficult.

https://apnews.com/c717475b7faf5e518e4de99e18f5318c
The movie theatre crowd are not happy, but unless things get worse they can probably get through December.   Or not.

https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/AMC/balance-sheet?p=AMC
https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/amc-theatres-to-reopen-theatres-in-us-in-august-2020-07-23 No real great idea - assuming that yahoo finance is accurate enough: given that AMC's book value isn't that great and its earnings aren't that great themselves, then sure it can go into liquidation. Perhaps, it will try to sell off property to stay afloat a bit past 2021? Current book value (NAV - intangible assets - goodwill) = 1,214,200 - 195,300 - 4,789,100 = -3,770,200

It seems like AMC still has some options, but the delay of the major releases of Tenet and Mulan certainly does not help things.

https://www.msn.com/en-us/movies/news/disney-postpones-e2-80-98mulan-e2-80-99-and-e2-80-98french-dispatch-e2-80-99-indefinitely-moves-all-e2-80-98star-wars-e2-80-99-and-e2-80-98avatar-e2-80-99-films-back-one-year/ar-BB176X4X I think I hear a death rattle ...

Sounding a little more 'dicey' at the moment. Maybe they'll work it out: "A group of AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. lenders opposing the company’s planned debt overhaul claims the theater chain violated terms of its credit agreement by failing to provide adequate information about the deal. The lenders, representing a majority of the company’s $2 billion term loan, sent AMC a notice of default..." 
(Source: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-07-21/amc-lenders-allege-default-with-company-debt-deal-on-the-horizon)
Increased my percentage chance for between October 1st and December 31st after news that Tenet is delayed indefinitely, weighed against the new loans that AMC has secured.

Films getting delayed and the deteriorating pandemic scene in the USA leads me to change the forecast: Before 1st Oct:                 + 15%
1st Oct to 31st Dec:         + 20%
Not before 1st Jan:           - 35% https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/disney-analyst-downgrade-longer-pandemic-impact-cinemas-closed-1303411
Predicting it will fold, but the date is uncertain. I don't see or hear the calvary coming to rescue them again.
No additional federal loans; AMC will shut down by September. With extensions, they may last to November.
softening my stance while I ponder.
A somewhat less optimistic forecast update, despite the recent financing deal:  https://seekingalpha.com/article/4358793-amc-entertainment-prepare-for-worst

AMC theatres just restructured its debt to stay afloat for longer. A massive chain like this will almost surely be kept afloat by the Trump administration who would like to keep entertainment monopolies in power.
They will get one more bailout.
Walmart is talking about putting drive ins in their parking lots

AMC has secured more debt to weather the storm out longer: https://www.wsj.com/articles/cinema-chain-amc-inks-financing-deal-to-help-it-survive-pandemic-11594418559 I’m still not a long term believer in the model of movie theaters or what their balance sheet looks like, but they’re finding ways to keep living on to fight another day.
Theaters are not reopening this year.  Studios will use the opportunity to move to digital premieres.
Rumored that AMC is working on a deal to avoid bankruptcy, for now: https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/07/08/why-amc-entertainment-stock-rose-nearly-10-in-earl.aspx
Bloomberg today:: AMC rose premarket after the WSJ reported it was close to a restructuring deal to help beat back a bankruptcy filing
I don't think they will, but if so, this will become apparent when their next FP is being evaluated. Q4 2020 or Q1 2021 I suppose...

This question is about one specific company with a large Chinese shareholder. They were able to recapitalize in Q2 and have pushed theater openings into August. Other chains may fail, but AMC is likely to survive this year. Overall it would seem that this business model will be under pressure for some time, the public will not like confined spaces crammed next to others.

"AMC had planned to begin a multi-phase reopening on July 15, with the goal of being fully operational by July 24. Now, it will begin the reopening process with 450 US theaters on July 30, and aims to have nearly all 600 of its US theaters fully up and running by "early August.""
[...]
"In the meantime, the uncertainty makes it almost impossible for businesses like AMC to plan for the future. Cineworld, which owns the Regal chain, followed suit in delaying theater openings on Tuesday, pushing them back until the end of July."
https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/30/investing/premarket-stocks-trading/index.html

Demise of this distribution model is accelerated by failure of US to contain spread which has impacted movie-goers and film production.  Early bankruptcy to secure favorable terms seems the best option given the likely prolonged impact of COVID-19

The bankruptcy rates are dropping and there is capital in the market. Continuing to move things down to lower chances. https://www.wsj.com/articles/wave-of-corporate-failures-stays-at-bayfor-now-11593509402?st=0yt854g4qza6ymu&reflink=article_copyURL_share
As movies are unlikely to open this year, theater chains in general are all going to have to file for bankruptcy.

leadership has little rationale to keep operating, bankruptcy gives them considerable ability to restructure their leases and contracts to get more favorable terms.   ultimately the movie producers need them to be viable, I would buy post bankruptcy emergence.

Guessing AMC will try to hang on as long as possible. A buyout could be a long-shot possibility. https://www.benzinga.com/analyst-ratings/analyst-color/20/06/16408055/will-amazon-or-netflix-buy-a-movie-theater-chain
when flu season hits with covid-19 the government will not allow a large group of people together.  they better have a system set up where you can stream new movies to your house.
Mulan delayed until August only, rather than worst case of a delay into late fall.

Disney considering delaying release of Mulan. If they do Tenent May follow. Given outbreaks in California and Texas, seems likely Disney will consider that delay.  Reducing likelihood of getting through the year pending Mulan announcement.

As people become more eager to venture into public, they will become accustomed to the necessary health measures. Ticket prices will increase due to fewer attendees and increased cleaning between showings. Movies will tend to be more accessible to an economically advantaged portion of society.
Unlikely to happen quickly as I would want to show survivability.  And unlikely I would wait until 2021 to file.  I would want the cover of 2020 economic disruption to blame.

With rising cases in the US, along with delays in major movie releases and poor showing in debit markets presents a number of challenges for AMC. Unless large numbers show up for Mulan and Tenet it's unlikely AMC survives without restructuring.
Increasing liklihood before end of year.
AMC will try to ride out the corona virus

Juggling percentages, assuming they can hold out for a while or maybe a miracle will happen, just like in the movies. Clearly, societal change may become permanent, and some business models may not recover. The theatre /studio model worked for a hundred years, but theatres no longer have a lock on audiences - there are so mnay choices for studios and consumers to reach each other.

They are not making decisions based on science and have already admitted to maybe not being able to recover. They are also in a huge fight with a major studio and claiming to not show their movies in their theater anymore. Additionally, I expect many stories of staff contracting covid19.

They're reopening in July, and looking to navigate their way through and find success while avoiding bankruptcy, so before October seems way to early to file. The CEO seems optimistic that they will recover (assuming he's being honest), so it doesn't fit they're current atmosphere and plan. It doesn't seem possible that they would file for bankruptcy within the next six months. I would think that it would be a last resort after all marketing, promotional, etc. measures have failed, OR if it appears that the industry (and movie theater business) is indeed dead and won't recover in the near future.
Juggling percentages. Assuming many theaters will go under, maybe not AMC. There are so many substitutes which are so more convenitent and safe, why bother with inflated prices, crowds, and virus?
The separation changed habits. Going to movies is affected. Plus, I expect the 2nd wave of infections starting with the cold season.

The traditional movie experience has been dying for quite some time and AMC does admit they might be unlikely to be able to stay in business: https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/03/media/amc-theatres-business-coronavirus/index.html It does feel to me like they are going to try and at least open in the Summer (for Tenet, Mulan, etc.) and see what happens, but unclear if they can last much longer than that. https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/business/story/2020-06-18/amc-theatres-reopen-coronavirus

AMC is drowning in 5$ billion in debt, already paying over 10% interest on new loans because of the risks involved.[1] Coronavirus cases are unlikely to meaningfully decrease this year in the US.[2] They have already shown ignorance of COVID risks or a willingness to endanger customers leading to a PR catastrophe that likely indicates weak/uninformed leadership.[3] Ultimately theatres are an over-costed, antiquated model whose time grows shorter as they steadily price their concessions out of the range of low-income individuals who have the greatest need for their service.  COVID is likely to accelerate theaters decline significantly while at the same time corporate has shown no interest in modernizing their service.  These days a single theatre visit can cost as much or more than several months subscription to unlimited use of a streaming service and that's just bad business.  That their debts exceeded their available cash by a factor of over a million should terrify anyone still holding stock.  However, large corporations regularly manage to stall accountability for years at a time.  Given the severity of their situation, it is possible they will go bankrupt this year but it seems more likely that they will drag the process out by taking increasingly unsustainable loans as they have already done in anticipation of a market revitalization that is unlikely to happen.   [1]https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/06/22/why-amc-entertainment-stock-was-sliding-today.aspx
[2]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States
[3]https://variety.com/2020/film/news/amc-coronavirus-movie-theaters-covid-19-1234642047/

Not knowing the expanse of the company, I believe there are several stages to go through, such as distancing, and ticket price raising, before many theaters do close. Then, it will take time to close some. And more time to determine the fate of the whole chain.
Too big too fall and should be able to ride out the wave until things return to normal.
Seems like they will be able to secure a loan or bailout plus once they start reopening kids will get bored in the summer and go watch movies

The movie theater industry is struggling and will continue to fallout. COVID-19 will certainly, accelerate this but AMC is in no position to make a pivot, and their debt holders will want them to stay in business to recover debt. Part of the worrisome part here is AMC is clearly trying to find creative ways to raise money and US cases are rising.  I think right now we should assume this business is in big trouble, but other retailers have also been in trouble and made it out. Pre COVID would have put chance of bankruptcy at less than 2 percent given fundamentals. Can continue to react but not overreact to the current situation and update over time.

What he said --> @cdob63. I'll add that theaters and air travel have a lot in common. The difference is there is not much of substitute for air travel, whereas theaters have lots of substitutes. Distancing and masks help, but less so in a closed space. Until there is a vaccine we are only kidding ourselves that some how things are now different.

Stock had been upgraded from sell to neutral, based on likelihood of movie theaters in the US and Europe being able to open in July/August. This prediction could change, as the COVID19 pandemic has spread further and faster recently. If movie theaters do not open, it could push AMC closer to bankruptcy, but for now, I’m holding to 100%, not before 1/01/21, final answer.
There may be some financial benefits to filing this year, if the long term isn’t looking substantially better, then I would expect it this year.

The recent mask contretemps does not stir one to confidence in AMC's management, but we'll see.  It will come down to whether people still want the relatively costly theatre experience, featuring uncomfortable seats, noisy neighbors, and huge overpriced vats of Coke and popcorn, all accompanied by free-floating virus.  Some number may have learned to prefer the greater comfort and lower cost of staying home and waiting for attractions to stream.  It is possible to speculate that this will be the more affluent proportion of the audience, which won't help the likes of AMC. It also appears that some number of multi-screen complexes will be reducing the number of screens in order to hold down queues, at least in states that maintain restrictions.  That will drain both ticket and concession revenue, as will the overarching question of how folks will respond to depleted household budgets.  The even longer answer to this involves knowing which AMC outlets are in effect local monopolies in their market areas.  I'm very much afraid I don't care enough to look into any of this, so I'll stick with SWAGs distilled from whatever is available in the press.

The company sits on almost 5 billion USD of long term debt and will post a combined loss of USD 5 billion in Q1 and Q2 of this year. The company throws up a good amount of cash with thin profit margins.  But, The company is backed by Chinese money and the business is fundamentally sound (from a long term perspective).  The debt could be packaged and restructured rather than filing. Hence the baseline prediction.
They will hang on and doing a pre-packaged BK takes a while.

Their losses for Q1 are $2.1B to $2.4B. The company has been operating sans revenue for months but were able to secure $500M in new debt to save them from bankruptcy. As of April, of April, their cash balance was $718.3 million. Their shares have doubled since their $2.08 price at the beginning of April and are now at ~$5.60. The theatres are opening at 30% capacity on July 15, then 40% on July 30, and so on til they reach full capacity by Thanksgiving. Mulan is opening mid July and Tenet on July 30 both expected to be blockbusters that will attract moviegoers, but at those limited capacities, and dependent on states and cities pandemic levels and regulations, it's all uncertain. 
The company's CEO had said they would not require facemasks but quickly reversed their decision die to public outcry. If pandemic is kept at bay in half the country and they are able to count on blockbuster releases, they should avoid bankruptcy before October. We'll have to see how things evolve.

(Initial forecast:) Coronavirus clearly has multiplied AMC's problems: (https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/06/16/3-reasons-to-sell-amc-stock.aspx, https://altmanzscoreplus.com/articles/AltmanZScorePlus_AMC_AMC_Entertainment_Holdings_Inc_Class_A.html, (https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/amc-theatres-bankruptcy-close-call-analyst-says-1297302). The company may find ways to hold on at least beyond October 1.
